title.value: Clinical Care Trajectory Assessment of Children With Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia and Neurodevelopmental Impairment
title.justification: The title is a direct excerpt from the paper, providing a precise description of the study.
title.quote: Clinical Care Trajectory Assessment of Children With Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia and Neurodevelopmental Impairment

extractions.description: The paper investigates the clinical trajectory of children with Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH) and Neurodevelopmental Impairment (NDI), focusing on the lived experience of families and their satisfaction with existing support resources. The study aims to highlight the long-term health surveillance required for these children and identifies areas that need improvement, such as communication among medical teams and the need for increased support, particularly in the initial years of life.

type.justification: The study involves data collection and analysis from a cohort of patients, their clinical follow-up, and their families' satisfaction with care, all indicative of empirical research.
type.quote: A multi-phase explanatory study (REB 2023e8964) was conducted. Phase 1: Review of clinical data for CDH-NDI patients attending a longitudinal follow-up clinic; Phase 2: Satisfaction assessment of CDH-NDI families with existing hospital resources.

name.justification: The study explicitly focuses on the assessment and management of clinical care in pediatric surgery, particularly for children with congenital conditions.
name.quote: Harvey E. Beardmore Division of Pediatric Surgery, Department of Pediatric Surgery, Montreal Children's Hospital

name.justification: The research involves a cohort of children and focuses on conditions diagnosed and managed from the neonatal stage.
name.quote: Division of Neonatology, Department of Pediatrics, Montreal Children's Hospital

name.justification: The paper discusses respiratory conditions and management strategies associated with CDH, indicating its relevance to respiratory medicine.
name.quote: Division of Respiratory Medicine, Department of Pediatrics, Montreal Children's Hospital
